Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. most likely root cause faults** that could explain the symptoms.\\n\\nEach fault:\\n- Must be localized to a single system component (node in the graph) of type `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- Must be restricted to the fault types listed in the INSTRUCTIONS section below\\n- Should include a plausible propagation path through the system that justifies how the fault led to the observed symptoms. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. checkoutservice-1 | hipstershop.CheckoutService/PlaceOrder (rpc) | PD\\n\\n## TASK\\nUse the knowledge graph and the observed alerts to identify the **three most likely root cause faults** that could explain the symptoms.\\n\\nEach fault:\\n- Must be localized to a single system component (node in the graph) of type `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- Must be restricted to the fault types listed in the INSTRUCTIONS section below\\n- Should include a plausible propagation path through the system that justifies how the fault led to the observed symptoms. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"4c94ad0b-d73e-4aff-b77c-5d159d836680\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"<think>\\nOkay, let's tackle this problem step by step. The user wants me to identify the three most likely root causes based on the provided knowledge graph and observed symptoms. First, I need to understand the system structure and the alerts given.\\n\\nLooking at the knowledge graph, there are multiple services, their instances, and hosts. The main components are services like frontend, cartservice, productcatalogservice, etc., hosted on nodes 5 and 6. The alerts include trace alerts (performance degradation, PD) and log alerts (errors in adservice-0 and frontend). \\n\\nThe key is to find a fault that can propagate through the system and explain these symptoms. Let's start by looking at the log alerts. The adservice-0 is throwing NullPointerExceptions and exceptions, which might indicate a problem in that service instance. Since adservice-0 is hosted on node-5, maybe there's a node-level issue causing this. However, the log errors are specific to adservice-0, so maybe it's a container-level fault here. \\n\\nLooking at the trace alerts, there's PD in multiple services communicating with productcatalogservice and cartservice. For example, frontend-2 to productcatalogservice-2, frontend-2 to cartservice-0, etc. This suggests that these services might be under load or experiencing delays. \\n\\nIf node-5 is hosting many services (like adservice-0, cartservice-0, productcatalogservice-0, etc.), a high node CPU load (type 10 or 11) could slow down these services, leading to PD in traces. The log errors in adservice-0 could be a result of the same underlying node issue, like the CPU being too busy to process requests properly, leading to exceptions. \\n\\nAnother possibility is a container-level fault in adservice-0, like memory issues (type 2) causing the NullPointerExceptions. If adservice-0's memory is exhausted, it might crash or throw errors, but the PD in other services might be due to a different cause. However, the PD in other services (like productcatalogservice) might not be directly related unless they're also on the same node. \\n\\nWait, the propagation path would be important. If node-5 is overloaded, then all services hosted there would suffer. Since adservice-0 is on node-5, and so are productcatalogservice-0, cartservice-0, etc., a node-level CPU issue would affect these services. The PD in traces to these services would be due to their own performance degradation. Also, the frontend services (like frontend-2) calling these services would experience PD. \\n\\nAnother angle: the log alerts in adservice-0 show frequent exceptions, which could be due to the service itself having a bug or misconfiguration. But the user instructions ask for the fault types listed, so container process termination (type 7) might be relevant if the service is crashing. However, the log entries are about exceptions occurring every few seconds, not the process terminating. So maybe it's a container-level issue like memory (type 2) causing the exceptions. \\n\\nBut the trace alerts are widespread across multiple services on node-5. If node-5's CPU is spiking (type 11), that would cause all services on it to be slow, leading to PD in their traces. The log errors in adservice-0 could be a symptom of the same node issue. \\n\\nSo the first root cause could be node-5 having a CPU spike. Let's check the justification. \\n\\nThe node-5 hosts adservice-0, which has log alerts of exceptions and NullPointerExceptions. If node-5's CPU is overloaded, it might be causing delays in processing requests to adservice-0, leading to timeouts or exceptions. Additionally, other services on node-5 (like productcatalogservice-0, cartservice-0) would also be slower, leading to the PD in their traces. The propagation path would be node-5 hosting these services, leading to their performance issues. \\n\\nThe second possible root cause could be the adservice-0 itself. If there's a container memory issue (type 2), leading to the exceptions. However, the PD in other services might not be explained unless there's a shared resource. But the PD in those services could be due to their own issues. However, since they are on the same node, maybe the memory issue in adservice-0 is part of a larger node problem. \\n\\nAlternatively, a container process termination (type 7) in adservice-0 could lead to it not responding, causing the frontend to fail to retrieve ads. Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. The user provided a bunch of logs and a knowledge graph. The main symptoms are a bunch of trace PDs (performance degradations) in the frontend services communicating with productcatalogservice instances, and later a lot of gRPC and HTTP errors related to Envoy and Istiod, which seems like a service mesh component. Also, there's a NullPointerException in adservice-0. \\n\\nFirst, I need to look at the structure of the system. The knowledge graph shows that multiple services are hosted on node-5 and node-6. For example, frontend, cartservice, checkoutservice, and many others are on node-5. The productcatalogservice instances are productcatalogservice-0, 1, 2, and 2-0. The productcatalog database is connected to productcatalogservice via data_flow.\\n\\nThe initial PDs in the frontend to productcatalogservice could be due to high latency or failures in the productcatalogservice itself. But looking at the logs, there's also a NullPointerException in adservice-0. However, the adservice is on node-5 as well, like adservice-0 is hosted on node-5. The problem with adservice-0 might be a specific issue with that instance, but the main symptoms are more widespread. \\n\\nThen there are the Envoy and Istiod-related errors. Envoy is a service mesh data plane, and Istiod is the control plane for Istio. If Istiod is down or unreachable, services using Istio (like the frontends) would have configuration issues, leading to connection errors. The logs mention \\\"lookup istiod.istio-system.svc on 168.254.20.10:53: read udp... i/o timeout\\\". This suggests that the DNS lookup for Istiod is failing, which could be a network issue or a problem with the DNS server on node-5. Since node-5 is hosting multiple services, including the frontends, a node-level issue like high CPU, memory, or network latency could be causing these DNS timeouts.\\n\\nAlso, the frontends are trying to communicate with Jaeger-collector and getting 503 errors. That could be due to the Jaeger service being down, but the error here is \\\"upstream_reset_before_response_started\\\", which might be because the frontends can't reach the Jaeger collector. However, the main issue seems to be the Envoy and Istiod errors, which are more systemic.\\n\\nLooking at the knowledge graph, all the frontends (frontend-0, 1, 2) are hosted on node-5. The adservice-0 is also on node-5. The productcatalogservice instances are on node-5 as well. So if node-5 is having a problem, it could affect all these services. The error logs about Envoy and Istiod being unreachable are coming from the frontends on node-5. That suggests that node-5's network connectivity might be the issue. The DNS errors for Istiod could be due to node-5's network stack being overwhelmed or experiencing packet loss, leading to timeouts when trying to reach Istiod.\\n\\nThe NullPointerException in adservice-0 could be a separate issue, but the main propagation seems to be on node-5. The initial PDs in the productcatalogservice could be due to high load on node-5, causing those services to be slow. However, the later logs point more towards a network issue on node-5, especially with DNS and gRPC streams.\\n\\nSo possible root causes could be:\\n\\n1. Node-5 has a network issue (like packet loss or high latency), causing DNS timeouts for Istiod and gRPC errors.\\n2. A service on node-5, like the DNS resolver, is down or misconfigured.\\n3. High CPU or memory on node-5 leading to service disruptions.\\n\\nLooking at the fault types, node-level network issues (like node network packet loss or latency) are possible. The fault type options include node network packet retransmission, packet loss, latency, etc. Since the symptoms include i/o timeouts and DNS lookup failures, node-level network packet loss (type 6) or latency (5) might be the cause. Alternatively, if the node's CPU is overloaded (type 10 or 11), that could cause delays in processing network packets, leading to timeouts.\\n\\nThe propagation path would involve node-5 hosting the frontends and other services, and the node's network issue causing the Envoy and Istiod errors, which in turn lead to the downstream errors in the services. For example, frontend-0 on node-5 can't reach Istiod, leading to configuration issues in Envoy, which causes the gRPC stream closures and subsequent request errors.\\n\\nAnother angle: The productcatalogservice is on node-5 as well. If node-5 is having a CPU or memory spike, it could slow down the productcatalogservice, leading to the initial PDs. Then, the network issues on node-5 would exacerbate the problem, leading to the later errors. But the main systemic issue seems to be the node-level network problem on node-5.\\n\\nThe NullPointerException in adservice-0 could be a separate fault, but it's a single instance. However, given the volume of errors in the frontends and the widespread network issues, node-5's network problem is more likely the primary root cause.\\n</think>\\n\\n# Root Cause Analysis\\n\\n## 1. Node-5 Network Packet Loss (Node-Level Fault)\\n- **Type**: 6. container packet loss\\n- **Description**: Network connectivity issues on node-5 caused intermittent packet loss, leading to DNS resolution failures for Istiod and gRPC stream closures in Envoy.\\n- **Location**: node-5 (Host)\\n- **Justification**:\\n  1. Multiple frontend instances on node-5 (frontend-0, frontend-1, frontend-2) exhibit identical DNS lookup failures for Istiod:\\n     - `read udp 172.20.8.x:xxxx->168.254.20.10:53: i/o timeout` (repeated across multiple timestamps)\\n  2. These failures directly correlate with gRPC stream closures in Envoy (`StreamAggregatedResources gRPC config stream closed`), which is critical for Istio service mesh configuration.\\n  3. The pattern of network failures (DNS timeouts + gRPC stream resets) suggests packet loss rather than application-level issues.\\n  4. Node-5 hosts 22 service instances (including all frontend instances) that exhibit these symptoms, indicating a systemic node-level issue.\\n- **Propagation Path**:\\n  `node-5 --(hosts)--> frontend-0 --(control_flow)--> productcatalogservice-1 --(data_flow)--> productcatalog`  \\n  `node-5 --(hosts)--> frontend-0 --(control_flow)--> checkoutservice-0 --(control_flow)--> emailservice-0`  \\n  `node-5 --(hosts)--> frontend-0 --(control_flow)--> cartservice-0 --(data_flow)--> redis-cart-0`\\n\\n## 2. Node-5 CPU Spiking (Node-Level Fault)\\n- **Type**: 11. node CPU spike\\n- **Description**: A sudden CPU spike on node-5 caused resource contention and delayed processing of critical service requests, leading to request errors and timeouts.\\n- **Location**: node-5 (Host)\\n- **Justification**:\\n  1. The volume of alerts (28+ instances across 8 minutes) suggests resource exhaustion rather than isolated incidents.\\n  2. Multiple services on node-5 (frontend, cartservice, checkoutservice, productcatalogservice) experience simultaneous performance degradations (PD alerts).\\n  3. The 503 Service Unavailable errors when uploading traces to Jaeger (`\\\"POST /api/traces HTTP/1.1\\\" 503`) suggest backend processing delays.\\n  4. The \\\"downstream_remote_disconnect\\\" errors indicate clients terminating connections due to unresponsiveness.\\n  5. Node-5 hosts 22 service instances (vs node-6 with 7) and would be more susceptible to resource contention.\\n- **Propagation Path**:\\n  `node-5 --(hosts)--> productcatalogservice-0 --(data_flow)--> productcatalog`  \\n  `node-5 --(hosts)--> checkoutservice-0 --(control_flow)--> paymentservice-0`  \\n  `node-5 --(hosts)--> frontend-0 --(control_flow)--> recommendationservice-0`\\n\\n## 3. adservice-0 Process Termination (Container-Level Fault)\\n- **Type**: 7. container process termination\\n- **Description**: The adservice-0 instance experienced an unexpected termination, causing a NullPointerException and disrupting its dependent services.\\n- **Location**: adservice-0 (Service_Instance)\\n- **Justification**:\\n  1. This aligns with the final alert: `\\\"severity: warning, message: failed to retrieve ads\\\"`.\\n  3. While this appears to be a single-instance issue, it could have cascading effects through its dependencies.\\n  4. The pattern is consistent with packet loss rather than application-specific failures.\\n\\n2. **Node-5 CPU Spiking** is secondary because:\\n   - While plausible, the evidence is indirect (inferred from error rates and service unavailability).\\n   - The specific network-related errors suggest a communications infrastructure issue rather than pure CPU exhaustion.\\n\\n3. **adservice-0 Process Termination** is tertiary because:\\n   - It appears to be a single-instance issue occurring after the primary faults.\\n   - Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. system component (node in the graph) of type `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- Must be restricted to the fault types listed in the INSTRUCTIONS section below\\n- Should include a plausible propagation path through the system that justifies how the fault led to the observed symptoms. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step.
